comments.author: lynnestrel94

comments.text:
Remember that this is my opinion and you don't have to agree with it. 

Okay, so after watching Big Hero 6, I decided to watch HTTYD 2 since it was 
getting hype over the year. I was a bit excited to watch this and I decided 
to go on Putlocker. Was it as awesome as everyone said it was? No. Was it 
terrible? No. It's just that it was okay, but I don't understand why people 
call this AMAZING or why it gets so much hype. HTTYD 1 was way better to be 
honest. I was a little disappointed. The plot was a bit rushed, but the 
movie was somewhat enjoyable at some parts, but not "the best".  I still 
thought it would change my mind about Big Hero 6, but it didn't. RoTG was 
also better than HTTYD 2. 
I'm sorry if I offended people with my review, I didn't mean for it to turn 
out that way. ﻿
comments.author: KaDYDJA T.

comments.author: KaDYDJA T.

comments.text:
I agree that the first film is superior to the second, for more than just 
pacing issues, but the visuals and a handful of good scenes carried it. As 
American animation goes, it's good, but Dreamworks can do better.

comments.text:
I've not watched some of the films you've mentioned but in regards to 
Httyd, I'm in agreement. The first one was more mature than most people 
envisaged and the story line was not rushed which was effective. As much as 
I liked the 2nd one I found it too rushed and that the ending was 
anticlimactic. The music for the 2nd one is stunning but I think the 
storyline was truly average- I also found you didn't get to see the 
characters in enough detail like in the first one :)
comments.author: Hugh Seager

comments.text:
I agree the movie did have pacing issues. But they have to cram so much 
story into an 1hr 42 min movie. The flying scenes were gorgeous and the 
movie made me want an actual dragon so bad..it has the best CGI for an 
animated movie so far. This movie made me feel like i'm actually in their 
world. But I respect your opinion.

comments.author: Jose Garcia

comments.text:
I think Astrid seemed to change because she opened up. She was very 
reserved in the first movie, but opened up more and more towards the end of 
that (and the tv series), especially around Hiccup.  I remember 
reading/hearing somewhere about that being planned that way - how her hair 
covered half her face at first, then gradually being swept aside as the 
movie progressed was even symbolic of that opening up.  Deep down, she is 
the same.  We just didn't know her as well before.
comments.author: opsatr

comments.text:
+KnifeInTheCrayonBox How Astrid changed is based heavily on what she went 
through in the first film, her determined attitude and competitive 
behaviour towards Hiccup being major points but softening up when she 
realized that he was still protecting everyone, just a different way. I 
always felt that Astrid was still herself, just a more caring self in the 
second film. 

Two of my all-time favourites without a doubt . :)

comments.author: kinshua

comments.text:
+kinshua I think the Jonsi song "Where no one goes" is a song...I guess you 
can say about Toothless and Hiccups' freedom when they fly together. So the 
other song fits very well with that message and high-spirited instruments 
they use.
comments.author: YouJustGotKnocked TheBarackOut

comments.text:
+kinshua Haha, I agree. I do see where you are coming from with the 
orchestral thing, and to be fair, it does make more sense.
comments.author: LoZfangurl

comments.text:
+LoZfangurl I definitely understand what you're saying and, you know, if I 
were to just listen to the Jonsi song by itself I would say that I like it. 
However, and this is just my own opinion, the two songs both create wildly 
different tones for this scene in my mind and even though they both could 
fit this scene I just prefer the Audiomachine song more. I think what leads 
me to think that is that most of the soundtrack is purely orchestral music 
and, for me, it seems out of place to put a song like this in the middle of 
the movie (kind of how in The Amazing Spiderman 2 after spoiler gwen dies 
and they had that random pop song which totally killed the mood for me). 
But to each their own!
comments.author: kinshua

comments.text:
what are you talking about? the song "where no one goes" fit perfectly with 
that scene. It makes you feel like you are above the clouds. just gotta try 
things new i guess
comments.author: kimo okamoto

comments.text:
Well, to each their own. I like both songs in the trailer and in the scene 
from the movie. I think the song used here (called "Beyond the Clouds" by 
Audiomachine) fits better with the teaser, because its meant to create 
suspense for the big reveal at the end, whereas "Where No One Goes" by 
Jónsi (The singer from Sigur Rós, if you've ever heard of them) fits better 
with the movie to create a more lighthearted setting to overshadow the 
[SPOILER FOR THOSE WHO HAVEN'T SEEN IT] chaos that Drago is causing by 
enslaving the dragons.

But hey, if you prefer one song over the other, I won't judge. Everyone has 
their own opinions. I personally love Jónsi's work, and I don't think 
rock/pop is the right way to describe it. He sings falsetto though, so I 
kind of get where you are going with that. Also, "Where No One Goes" 
actually does have an orchestra playing. You might just not have noticed it 
because you could have been distracted by the vocals or something.
comments.author: LoZfangurl

comments.text:
I agree that this should have been used for this scene, but I guess the 
reason why they didn't use it is because it's not composed by John Powell. 
This music is by some other group of musicians. Maybe they only approved of 
their track to be used in the teaser trailer? 
Anyways, I still like "Where no one goes" by Jonsi. Since his song "Sticks 
and Stones" was used in the first movie's end credits it was easy to get 
him to do more music for the 2nd one.
comments.author: Yaya per

comments.text:
I know. The soundtrack really fit the movie well, but I didn't like the pop 
song much. If they kept the music from this video I think I'd've enjoyed it 
more.

comments.author: nukeclears

comments.text:
Let me just say, this is one of the best movies of all time, including 
HTTYD. It has the key ingredients that are missing in many movies and I 
couldn't be more prouder of DreamWorks. :) The portrayal of emotions are 
spot on, the graphics are ay-May-zing and the characters have such strong 
personalities. Personally, I believe this movie was an emotional roller 
coaster ride for me. When there were emotional moments, half way through, 
something funny would pop up outta no where. I got all teary eyed in many 
of the scenes, and I was so amazed by how smart Dean and Chris are on how 
they directed and produced both of these movies. #1 movie out there (for 
me), and it most probably always will be. :) just had to put it out there.﻿

comments.text:
I have seen this movie and I RECOMMEND you to see this movie it's an 
amazing movie and it deserves to have a big box office chance because it's 
the best movie I have ever seen. It has the best animation scenes I have 
ever seen since I have seen Frozen. This movie is better than Frozen.
comments.author: John Lewis

comments.text:
Guys, don't look for it on websites while the film is still in theatres. 
Dreamworks needs all the money it can get at the moment, and HTTYD 2 really 
deserves to be a big box office hit (because it unfortunately isn't at the 
moment).
Besides, if you find a website that 'allows' you to watch this movie while 
it's still in theatres, then the website most likely won't work. 
Just save up! Or go with a friend!
